entities: erivera_2027 — freshman, history major
Prof. Andersen — HIST 215 instructor
StudyBuddy AI Tutor
HIST 215 — Modern European History (Fall 2025)
Essay assignment: 'Evaluate whether the Treaty of Versailles made World War II inevitable'
Student's first draft — 1,200 words, submitted as pasted text in chat
Thesis statement: 'The Treaty of Versailles was the primary cause of World War II because it humiliated Germany'
Required sources: minimum 5 scholarly sources, Chicago citation style
John Maynard Keynes — 'The Economic Consequences of the Peace' (1919)
Margaret MacMillan — 'Paris 1919: Six Months That Changed the World' (2001)
Course rubric categories: Thesis clarity, Evidence use, Argumentation, Writing mechanics
actions: erivera_2027 pastes full 1,200-word draft and asks 'can you give me feedback on my essay structure?'
Tutor identifies that the thesis is too one-dimensional and suggests considering counterarguments
Tutor points out that paragraphs 2 and 3 both cover the same economic grievances and suggests consolidating
erivera_2027 asks 'what would a stronger thesis look like that isn't just blaming Versailles for everything?'
Tutor provides three example thesis frameworks that acknowledge complexity without giving a specific thesis

Student rewrites thesis in chat: 'While the Treaty of Versailles created conditions for extremism, the rise of the Nazi party depended on a convergence of economic crisis, political instability, and ideological appeal'
Tutor gives feedback on the revised thesis — notes it is more nuanced but could be tighter
erivera_2027 asks how to integrate Keynes's argument without just summarizing it
Tutor explains the difference between summarizing a source and using it as evidence for a claim
Student pastes revised paragraph 2 incorporating Keynes and asks 'is this better?'
Tutor provides line-level feedback on paragraph 2 — flags a dropped quotation and a missing page number in citation
erivera_2027 asks about Chicago footnote format for a book with a translator
Tutor explains Chicago 17th edition footnote format for translated works with example
Student asks if they need a bibliography separate from footnotes
Tutor clarifies: Chicago notes-bibliography style requires both footnotes and a bibliography
quotes: erivera_2027: 'ok so my prof said the thesis needs to be arguable not just a fact. is mine arguable?'
Tutor: 'Your current thesis states a causal relationship as though it's settled. A stronger approach would acknowledge the debate — historians disagree about how directly Versailles led to WWII.'
erivera_2027: 'wait so should I pick a side or stay neutral'
Tutor: 'You should take a clear position, but show you've considered the strongest counterarguments. This demonstrates analytical depth rather than mere opinion.'
erivera_2027: 'lol ok that makes sense. lemme try rewriting it real quick'
erivera_2027: 'hmm what about the part where I talk about the war guilt clause? my prof circled that and wrote 'develop' next to it'

Tutor: 'The war guilt clause (Article 231) is central to your argument. Right now you mention it in one sentence. You could expand by discussing both the intended function of the clause and how it was received in Germany.'
erivera_2027: 'oh man I didn't even think about how germans actually reacted to it. do you know any good sources for that?'

Tutor: 'Sally Marks's article "The Myths of Reparations" (1978) in Central European History offers a revisionist perspective. Also consider examining Gerhard Weinberg's work on the German perception of Versailles.'
details: Session lasted 47 minutes with 32 turns
Student's draft had no in-text citations — only a works cited list at the bottom
Tutor flagged 3 paragraphs that made claims without supporting evidence
Student's original thesis was a single sentence; revised thesis is two sentences
Tutor suggested the student visit the campus writing center for additional line-editing help
Essay due date: September 19, 2025
Student's draft used 'World War 2' inconsistently — sometimes 'WWII', sometimes 'WW2'
Tutor recommended consistent formatting per Chicago style: 'World War II'

actions: tnguyen_2026 opens session asking 'hey I have a close reading due friday and I want to make sure my analysis is deep enough'

entities: kwilliams_2025 — senior, philosophy major
Prof. Okafor — PHIL 301 instructor
StudyBuddy AI Tutor
PHIL 301 — Ethics and Moral Theory (Fall 2025)
Paper assignment: 'Reconstruct and evaluate one of Peter Singer's arguments from Practical Ethics'
Student's draft — 2,400 words on Singer's argument against speciesism
Peter Singer — 'Practical Ethics' (3rd edition, 2011)
Tom Regan — 'The Case for Animal Rights' (1983)
Bernard Williams — 'Ethics and the Limits of Philosophy' (1985)
Chicago author-date citation style required
Course emphasis: argument reconstruction and logical evaluation
actions: kwilliams_2025 opens session: 'I need feedback on my Singer paper before I turn it in Wednesday'
Student pastes 2,400-word draft arguing that Singer's utilitarian case against speciesism fails
Tutor reads the draft and identifies the student's main objection: Singer's principle of equal consideration is too demanding
Tutor notes that the argument reconstruction section (section 2) is incomplete — missing Singer's key premise about the capacity for suffering
kwilliams_2025 says 'yeah I wasn't sure how to state his premise without it sounding like I agree with him'
Tutor explains the difference between reconstructing an argument charitably and endorsing it
Student asks for help identifying the logical structure of Singer's argument — 'like is it a syllogism or what'
Tutor breaks down Singer's argument into a standard form with premises and conclusion
kwilliams_2025 asks 'ok so my objection is basically that premise 2 doesn't work right? how do I make that clearer'
Tutor points out that the student's objection is stated as an intuition rather than an argument — suggests the student provide reasons why premise 2 fails
Student drafts a revised objection paragraph in chat and asks for feedback
Tutor highlights that the revised objection now has a logical structure but relies on an unstated assumption about moral status
kwilliams_2025 asks how to address the anticipated rebuttal from a utilitarian perspective
Tutor suggests consulting Regan's rights-based alternative to contrast with Singer's utilitarian framework
Student asks about the difference between act and rule utilitarianism and whether it matters for their objection
Tutor explains the distinction and notes that Singer's argument primarily draws on preference utilitarianism
kwilliams_2025 asks if they need a conclusion that 'picks a side' or just evaluates the argument
quotes: kwilliams_2025: 'my prof keeps saying we need to be charitable to the argument before we attack it. idk what that means in practice'

Tutor: 'Charitable reconstruction means presenting the argument in its strongest possible form. You should state Singer's premises as clearly and persuasively as you can before raising objections. This shows you've understood the argument, not just found something to disagree with.'
kwilliams_2025: 'ok I think I get it. so like steel-manning basically?'
Tutor: 'Exactly — the philosophical term is the "principle of charity." Your reconstruction should make someone unfamiliar with Singer understand why the argument is compelling.'

kwilliams_2025: 'alright here's my rewrite of section 2: Singer argues that (1) suffering is morally relevant regardless of species, (2) equal interests deserve equal moral consideration, therefore (3) practices that cause animal suffering for trivial human benefit are morally impermissible'

Tutor: 'This is much clearer. One refinement: Singer's argument applies specifically to the *capacity* for suffering rather than the experience of suffering in any given moment. This distinction matters for your objection.'
kwilliams_2025: 'oh that's a good point. so my objection about 'degrees of suffering' is actually weaker than I thought huh'

Tutor: 'Not necessarily weaker, but you may need to reframe it. If you're arguing that the capacity for suffering differs between species in morally relevant ways, you'll need to engage with Singer's response to that objection in Chapter 3.'
details: Session lasted 41 minutes with 28 turns
Student's original draft had argument reconstruction in 1 paragraph; tutor recommended expanding to 2-3 paragraphs
The draft's bibliography listed 7 sources but only 3 were cited in the text
Tutor identified 2 instances where the student attributed claims to Singer that are actually Regan's positions
Student's conclusion was only 4 sentences — tutor recommended expanding to summarize the evaluation
Paper due date: September 24, 2025
Required length: 2,500-3,000 words
Prof. Okafor's rubric weights argument reconstruction at 40% of the grade
Tutor recommended the student re-read Singer Chapter 3 before finalizing the objection section

entities: lmorales_2027 — freshman, undeclared major
Prof. Huang — HIST 110 instructor
StudyBuddy AI Tutor
HIST 110 — World History to 1500 (Fall 2025)
Primary source analysis assignment: analyze an excerpt from Ibn Battuta's 'Rihla' (Travels)
Student's draft — 900 words, mostly summary with minimal analysis
Ibn Battuta — 'Rihla' (c. 1355), excerpt on the Mali Empire and Mansa Musa's court
Ross Dunn — 'The Adventures of Ibn Battuta' (2004)
Assignment handout with guiding questions: What does the source reveal about trade networks? What biases does the author bring?
Chicago notes-bibliography citation style required
actions: lmorales_2027 opens session: 'hi I have a primary source analysis and I'm confused about what analysis actually means vs just summarizing'
Student pastes their 900-word draft which retells what Ibn Battuta describes at Mansa Musa's court
Tutor reads the draft and notes it is almost entirely summary — only the last 2 sentences attempt analysis
Tutor asks the student what questions they're trying to answer about the source
lmorales_2027 pastes the assignment handout with guiding questions
Tutor explains the difference between summary ('Ibn Battuta describes X') and analysis ('Ibn Battuta's description of X reveals Y about the context')
Student asks 'so like I need to say what the source tells us about stuff that ibn battuta might not have even meant to tell us?'
Tutor agrees — reading between the lines for what the source reveals about its historical context, unintentionally
lmorales_2027 identifies that Ibn Battuta seems surprised by the wealth of Mali — asks if that counts as a bias
Tutor explains the concept of authorial perspective and how Battuta's background as a Moroccan scholar shaped his observations
Student attempts to rewrite their opening paragraph as analysis rather than summary
Tutor gives feedback on the rewrite: the analysis is there but the student needs to cite specific passages from the source as evidence
lmorales_2027 asks how to cite a primary source that was assigned as a PDF scan with no page numbers
Tutor explains citing by section or paragraph number when page numbers aren't available
Student asks whether they can use the Ross Dunn book as a secondary source to provide context
Tutor says yes — secondary sources contextualize the primary source but the analysis should focus on the primary text
lmorales_2027 asks 'should I write about everything in the excerpt or just pick one theme?'
quotes: lmorales_2027: 'my high school teacher always said just tell them what happened but my prof says thats not analysis??'

Tutor: 'In college history courses, summary demonstrates comprehension but analysis demonstrates critical thinking. Your professor wants you to interrogate the source — ask what it reveals, what it conceals, and why.'
lmorales_2027: 'ok I think I see. so like when ibn battuta talks about the gold it's not just about gold — it's about how outsiders saw mali?'

Tutor: 'Exactly. You could examine what Ibn Battuta chose to emphasize and what he might have omitted. His detailed descriptions of wealth and court ceremony tell us about what impressed a 14th-century Moroccan traveler.'
lmorales_2027: 'ohhh ok. and the fact that he wrote it down at all means mali was important enough for him to go there'

Tutor: 'That's a strong analytical observation. You could develop it further by noting that Ibn Battuta's journey to Mali was part of broader trans-Saharan trade networks that connected West Africa to the Islamic world.'
lmorales_2027: 'here's my new first paragraph: [pastes revised text] — is this analysis or still too summary-ish?'

Tutor: 'This is much better. You're now making claims about the source rather than just reporting its contents. One suggestion: your second sentence makes an analytical claim but doesn't point to a specific passage. Add a direct quotation from the excerpt to ground it.'
details: Session lasted 38 minutes with 26 turns
Student's original 900-word draft was below the 1,500-word minimum
After the session, student planned to rewrite with analysis-focused structure
Tutor identified that 7 of the student's 9 paragraphs were pure summary
The assigned excerpt was approximately 3 pages from the Rihla covering Battuta's visit to Mali in 1352
Assignment due date: October 1, 2025
This was lmorales_2027's first college writing assignment
Tutor suggested the student try the 'observation → inference → significance' framework for each paragraph
Student expressed difficulty distinguishing between what Ibn Battuta 'says' and what the text 'reveals'

entities: tnguyen_2026 — junior, English and comparative literature double major

Edward Said — 'Culture and Imperialism' (1993)
Chinua Achebe — 'An Image of Africa: Racism in Conrad's Heart of Darkness' (1977)
Patrick Brantlinger — 'Rule of Darkness: British Literature and Imperialism, 1830-1914' (2013)
MLA 9th edition citation format
actions: tnguyen_2026 opens session: 'back again lol. midterm essay comparing two victorian novels and empire. can you look at my draft?'
Student pastes 2,600-word comparative essay draft
Tutor reads the draft and notes the comparative structure: alternating paragraphs between Brontë and Conrad rather than integrated comparison
Tutor suggests a point-by-point structure would strengthen the comparative analysis
tnguyen_2026 asks 'what do you mean by point-by-point? like I talk about both books in every paragraph?'
Tutor explains block vs. point-by-point comparative essay structures with brief examples
Student says their draft currently treats Jane Eyre in paragraphs 2-4 and Heart of Darkness in paragraphs 5-7
Tutor identifies that the student makes similar arguments about both novels but doesn't draw explicit connections between them
tnguyen_2026 asks for feedback on their use of Said's concept of 'contrapuntal reading'
Tutor notes the student defines contrapuntal reading correctly but only applies it to Heart of Darkness, not Jane Eyre
Student realizes they could use contrapuntal reading as the unifying framework for both texts
Tutor provides feedback on the draft's introduction — thesis is too vague ('both novels deal with empire')
tnguyen_2026 rewrites thesis to specify what aspect of empire the comparison illuminates
Tutor gives feedback on the revised thesis — stronger but the comparative claim still needs sharpening
Student asks how to handle the anachronism of comparing Brontë (1847) and Conrad (1899) — 'is it fair to compare them when they're 50 years apart?'
Tutor explains that the assignment asks about treatment of empire across the Victorian period — chronological range is a feature, not a bug
tnguyen_2026 asks about integrating Achebe's critique of Conrad — 'can I use Achebe to argue Conrad is worse than Brontë on empire?'
quotes: tnguyen_2026: 'my prof said my last paper had 'strong close reading but needs more theoretical framing' so I'm trying to use said more'

Tutor: 'Using Said as a theoretical framework is appropriate here. The key is applying contrapuntal reading to both texts consistently. Right now, your Conrad section engages Said extensively but your Brontë section relies only on Gilbert and Gubar.'
tnguyen_2026: 'yeah bc I already used gilbert and gubar for the last paper and I'm more comfortable with them. said is harder to apply to jane eyre'

Tutor: 'Said actually discusses Jane Eyre in Culture and Imperialism — specifically the role of Bertha Mason as a colonial subject. You could draw on his reading to create a parallel with your Conrad analysis.'
tnguyen_2026: 'omg I totally forgot he talks about jane eyre. ok that fixes my problem then'

tnguyen_2026: 'here's my new thesis: While both Brontë and Conrad engage with the British imperial project, a contrapuntal reading reveals that Brontë domesticates colonial violence through the figure of Bertha Mason, whereas Conrad aestheticizes it through Marlow's narrative detachment'

Tutor: 'This is significantly stronger — it makes a specific comparative claim with distinct terms for each text (domesticates vs. aestheticizes). This will give your body paragraphs clear analytical targets.'
tnguyen_2026: 'should I also bring in brantlinger or is 3 critics too many for a midterm essay'

Tutor: 'Three critics is manageable if each serves a distinct function. Use Said as your primary framework, Achebe for the Conrad critique, and Brantlinger for broader historical context. Avoid letting any one critic overwhelm your own argument.'
details: Session lasted 44 minutes with 30 turns
This is tnguyen_2026's second session on StudyBuddy this semester — first was the Jane Eyre close reading (Sept 17)

entities: dkim_2026 — sophomore, political science major, philosophy minor
Prof. Castellano — PHIL 220 instructor
StudyBuddy AI Tutor
PHIL 220 — Introduction to Political Philosophy (Fall 2025)
Response paper assignment: 'Is Rawls's difference principle compatible with a meritocratic society?'
Student's draft — 2,100 words arguing that the difference principle undermines meritocracy
John Rawls — 'A Theory of Justice' (revised edition, 1999)
Robert Nozick — 'Anarchy, State, and Utopia' (1974)
Michael Sandel — 'The Tyranny of Merit' (2020)
Susan Moller Okin — 'Justice, Gender, and the Family' (1989)
Chicago author-date citation style
Key concepts: original position, veil of ignorance, difference principle, maximin strategy
actions: dkim_2026 opens session: 'hi I have a response paper on rawls and I want to check if my argument actually works logically'
Student pastes 2,100-word draft
Tutor reads the draft and identifies the central claim: the difference principle creates disincentives that undermine the meritocratic allocation of resources
Tutor notes that the student's argument conflates 'meritocracy' with 'free market outcomes' and suggests distinguishing them
dkim_2026 asks 'wait aren't they the same thing? if people earn more because they're better at their jobs isn't that meritocracy?'
Tutor explains Rawls's distinction between natural talents (morally arbitrary) and effort, and how this complicates meritocratic claims
Student says 'oh so rawls would say meritocracy is already unfair because talents are random. I didn't get that from the reading'
Tutor points to specific sections of A Theory of Justice where Rawls addresses natural talents and moral desert
dkim_2026 asks if they should abandon their thesis or modify it
Tutor suggests the student could refine the thesis: instead of arguing the difference principle undermines meritocracy, argue it redefines what counts as a just outcome
Student drafts a revised thesis in chat incorporating the moral arbitrariness of natural talents
Tutor gives feedback on the revised thesis — notes it now engages with Rawls's actual reasoning rather than a straw man
dkim_2026 asks how to use Nozick as a counterpoint — 'my prof wants us to engage with at least one critic'
Tutor suggests Nozick's entitlement theory as the strongest libertarian objection to the difference principle
Student asks about the Wilt Chamberlain thought experiment and whether they need to include it
Tutor explains the Wilt Chamberlain argument and how it challenges patterned theories of justice like Rawls's
dkim_2026 asks 'can I also use sandel? his book is about meritocracy and I already read it for another class'
Tutor notes Sandel's critique of meritocracy could strengthen the argument — Sandel argues meritocracy itself is morally corrosive, which aligns with Rawls
Student pastes a revised concluding paragraph and asks for feedback
quotes: dkim_2026: 'honestly I picked this topic because I thought it would be easy to argue against rawls but now I realize his argument is more complicated than I thought'

Tutor: 'That's actually a productive discovery. The strongest papers often come from engaging seriously with an argument you initially disagreed with. You don't have to change your conclusion — just show you've understood Rawls's reasoning.'

dkim_2026: 'ok here's my new thesis: Rawls's difference principle does not undermine meritocracy but rather exposes the morally arbitrary foundations of meritocratic claims, suggesting that just outcomes require institutional correction of unearned advantages'

Tutor: 'This is a substantial improvement. You've moved from attacking Rawls to engaging with his framework on its own terms. The phrase "morally arbitrary foundations" directly references Rawls's language, which shows close engagement with the text.'
dkim_2026: 'lol so I basically switched sides during the paper. is that ok?'

Tutor: 'Many philosophers consider this a sign of intellectual honesty. Your paper can acknowledge your initial intuition and then explain why Rawls's argument changed your assessment. This shows the argumentative journey.'
dkim_2026: 'my conclusion feels weak tho. like I just restate my thesis. how do I make it do more?'

Tutor: 'Your conclusion could extend the argument — consider what implications the difference principle has for specific contemporary policies, or what questions Rawls's framework leaves unanswered. Don't introduce new arguments, but point toward what comes next.'
dkim_2026: 'ok what about something about how okin extends rawls to gender? that could be a future direction'
details: Session lasted 50 minutes with 34 turns
Student's draft originally had a thesis that Rawls is 'anti-meritocracy' — revised to a more nuanced position
Tutor identified 4 places where the student attributed views to Rawls without citing specific sections of A Theory of Justice
Student's Nozick section was added during the session — original draft only referenced Rawls
The draft's structure was introduction-body-body-body-conclusion; tutor recommended adding a section for the Nozickian objection
Paper due date: October 13, 2025
Required length: 2,000-2,500 words
dkim_2026 mentioned they are considering a philosophy minor and this paper is part of their exploration
Tutor recommended the student read Rawls sections 12-17 more carefully before finalizing

metadata.subject: HIST 405 — Seminar in American Social Movements

entities: acooper_2025 — senior, history major with concentration in American studies
Prof. Delgado — HIST 405 instructor
StudyBuddy AI Tutor
HIST 405 — Seminar in American Social Movements (Fall 2025)
Historiographic essay: 'How has the historiography of the Civil Rights Movement shifted since 1990?'
Student's draft — 3,200 words covering three historiographic waves
Jacquelyn Dowd Hall — 'The Long Civil Rights Movement and the Political Uses of the Past' (2005)
Jeanne Theoharis — 'A More Beautiful and Terrible History' (2018)
Charles Payne — 'I've Got the Light of Freedom: The Organizing Tradition and the Mississippi Freedom Struggle' (1995)
Glenda Gilmore — 'Defying Dixie: The Radical Roots of Civil Rights, 1919-1950' (2008)
Taylor Branch — 'Parting the Waters: America in the King Years 1954-63' (1988)
Chicago notes-bibliography citation style
Course requirement: seminar paper must be suitable for potential conference presentation
actions: acooper_2025 opens session: 'writing my seminar paper on civil rights historiography. it's 3200 words and I need it to be conference-ready. can you help with structure and argument?'
Student pastes the 3,200-word draft

Tutor reads the draft and identifies three distinct phases in the student's historiographic narrative: classical narrative (Branch), long movement thesis (Hall), and recent local/grassroots studies (Payne, Theoharis)
Tutor notes the draft describes each phase but doesn't analyze why the shifts occurred
acooper_2025 asks 'what do you mean by why the shifts occurred? like what caused historians to change their approach?'
Tutor explains that historiographic essays should address the intellectual and political contexts that prompted methodological shifts — not just describe the scholarship chronologically
Student asks 'so like I should talk about how the rise of social history in the 80s influenced civil rights scholarship?'
Tutor agrees and suggests linking each historiographic wave to broader trends in the discipline
acooper_2025 asks for feedback on their treatment of the 'long civil rights movement' thesis
Tutor notes the Hall section is the strongest but the student treats it as established consensus when it's actually contested
Student asks who contests the long movement thesis — 'I thought everyone agreed with hall at this point'
Tutor references Sundiata Keita Cha-Jua and Clarence Lang's critique (2007) that the long movement framework dilutes the specificity of the 1950s-60s movement
acooper_2025 asks 'should I take a side or just present both positions?'
Tutor explains that a historiographic essay should evaluate the strengths and limitations of each approach while potentially arguing for one framework's utility
Student realizes their draft lacks a clear argument about which approach is most productive
Tutor suggests the student could argue that local/grassroots studies (Payne, Theoharis) synthesize the strengths of both the classical narrative and the long movement thesis
acooper_2025 drafts a new thesis incorporating this synthesis argument
Tutor gives feedback on the new thesis — strong but needs to specify what 'synthesis' means concretely
Student asks about formatting for a potential conference submission — abstract requirements, length norms
Tutor provides general guidance on history conference paper formats: 20-25 minute read-aloud (~3,000-4,000 words), abstract of 250 words
quotes: acooper_2025: 'my prof said this could be a conference paper if I tighten the argument. I've never submitted to a conference before so I'm trying to make it actually good'

Tutor: 'Conference papers typically have a sharper, more focused argument than seminar papers. Your draft covers a lot of ground — which is good for a literature review — but a conference version might narrow to one specific historiographic debate.'
acooper_2025: 'do you think the long movement debate is specific enough for a conference paper?'

Tutor: 'The long movement debate is well-established enough to have a rich literature but still contested enough to be interesting. You could frame your paper as an intervention in that debate rather than a survey of it.'

acooper_2025: 'ok here's my new thesis: Recent grassroots studies of the civil rights movement by scholars like Payne and Theoharis resolve the tension between the classical King-centric narrative and Hall's long movement thesis by demonstrating that local organizing traditions both preceded and extended beyond the national legislative victories of 1964-65'

Tutor: 'This is a strong, arguable thesis. It positions your paper as making a claim about the field rather than merely summarizing it. One suggestion: consider whether "resolve" is too strong — you might say "productively navigate" or "reframe" the tension instead.'
acooper_2025: 'good point. resolve makes it sound like the debate is over. reframe is better'
acooper_2025: 'also my prof marked a section where I describe payne's methodology. she wrote 'how does this differ from branch?' — should I add a direct comparison?'

Tutor: 'Yes — comparing Payne's oral-history-centered methodology with Branch's narrative approach would demonstrate why the methodological shift matters for the conclusions each historian draws. It's a concrete way to show how historiographic frameworks shape outcomes.'
details: Session lasted 56 minutes with 38 turns
Student's draft organized chronologically: classical (1960s-80s), long movement (2000s), grassroots/local (2010s-present)
Tutor identified that 5 paragraphs in the draft lacked topic sentences
Student's original thesis was descriptive ('the historiography of the civil rights movement has changed in three major waves') rather than argumentative
The Theoharis section contained 2 block quotations over 4 lines each — tutor suggested integrating shorter quotations instead
Student had not yet read the Cha-Jua and Lang critique and planned to add it based on the session
Paper due date: October 21, 2025 (seminar paper), potential conference submission in January 2026
Required length: 4,000-5,000 words for the seminar version
acooper_2025 mentioned they are applying to history graduate programs and want this paper for their writing sample
Tutor recommended adding a brief section on the limits of the grassroots approach to strengthen the argument
